newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk trader sells Iraq 2,300-T sugar, to sell more.
newsitem.headline: Turk trader sells Iraq 2,300-T sugar, to sell more.

text.p: A Turkish sugar trading company, Lebsan, said on Monday it had sold 2,300 tonnes of white ICUMSA-45 sugar to Iraq in January and 200 tonnes to Iran.
Okkes Leblebici, general manager of the company, told Reuters the company would continue to sell sugar to the two countries.

"The sales to Iraq are made to local companies there and they are normal humanitarian sales," he said, referring to Iraq's purchases since the Gulf War under a U.N.-monitored scheme which is separate from the current U.N. oil-for-food sales plan.
"There will be more sales to these countries in the near future," he said. "All sugar we trade is of ICUMSA-45 quality," he said.

Leblebici said Lebsan planned to sell the sugar in batches of 1,000 tonnes from two customs areas in Turkey -- one in Agri, which borders Iran and Armenia, and the other in the southeastern city of Gaziantep, where the company is based.
"We use Agri for sales to Iran and Gaziantep for Iraq," he said.
He said sales to Iran could be passed on to Uzbekistan and Azerbaijan. He would not give details on prices.
Lebsan bought 46,000 tonnes of white sugar from Turkseker, Turkey's state sugar refineries, through a tender.
Leblebici said its Turkseker purchase was being shipped from Agri and the southeastern Elbistan refineries.
